description: From Latin sēnsibilis (“perceptible by the senses, having feeling, sensible”), from sentiō (“to feel, perceive”).

adjectives.description: sensible (comparative more sensible, superlative most sensible or sensiblest)

entries.meaning: Acting with or showing good sense; able to make good judgements based on reason, or reflecting such ability.
examples: They ask questions of someone who thinks he's got something sensible to say on some matter when actually he hasn't.

entries.meaning: Characterized more by usefulness, practicality, or comfort than by attractiveness, formality, or fashionableness, especially of clothing.
examples: I only wear high heels on formal occasions; otherwise, I prefer sensible shoes.

entries.meaning: (especially formally) Able to be sensed by the senses or the psyche; able to be perceived.
examples: Air is sensible to the Touch by its Motion, and by its Resistance to Bodies moved in it.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Liable to external impression; easily affected; sensitive.
(archaic) Of or pertaining to the senses; sensory.
(archaic) Cognizant; having the perception of something; aware of something.
examples: He cannot think at any time, waking or sleeping, without being sensible of it.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) That which impresses itself on the senses; anything perceptible.
examples: Aristotle distinguished sensibles into common and proper.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) That which has sensibility; a sensitive being.
examples: This melancholy extends itself not to men only, but even to vegetals and sensibles.
